headline: Asian Coleslaw
description: This Asian coleslaw recipe combines 3 cabbage varieties and crunchy veggies in a deliciously light and creamy peanut butter and soy-ginger dressing.

video.description: This coleslaw makes a delicious side dish. The secret? Peanut butter.
video.name: Asian Coleslaw

name: Asian Coleslaw

recipeInstructions.text: Prepare the peanut dressing: Whisk together rice vinegar, oil, peanut butter, soy sauce, brown sugar, ginger, and garlic in a medium bowl. Set aside.
Make the cabbage salad: Mix green cabbage, red cabbage, napa cabbage, red bell peppers, carrots, green onions, and cilantro in a large bowl.
Toss salad together with peanut dressing just before serving.

review.reviewBody: It's great. I've made it three times. I did add some kick with 2 T of cumin jalapeno dressing to the dressing.
peanut sauce was tasty /and the ingredients could serve 6
I halved the recipe, used sesame instead of vegetable oil, and chunky peanut butter instead of creamy. It was delicious!!!!

Very good. Followed the recipe for the dressing, used olive oil, and did not find it too oily. Used what I had on hand for veggies: napa and red cabbage, carrot, daikon radish, green onion, and cilantro, no green cabbage or peppers. Added chopped, roasted almonds for crunch. Chopped peanut would have been good too. Still using up my fall cabbage harvest so will definitely make again.
Weird consistency (thick) and flavor (tasted like peanut butter on cabbage). I made it exactly as written.

Omitted peanut butter and garlic.
 Made the dressing with 3 tbsp. rice vinegar, 2 tbsp. oil, 1 tbsp. soy sauce, 1/2 tbsp. brown sugar, 1/4 tsp. ginger, 1/4 C. fresh ch. cilantro, juice of 1/2 lime and 1/8 tsp. chili paste. Excellent result..
Did not like this. I made for a dinner party and it was not well received. No one ate it. The peanut sauce tasted odd
I substituted pb powder and this was delicious. Am going to make this dressing again!!
It was good! Six thumbs up! (There’s three of us in the house and we all have two thumbs!)

I think this good. I made a few tweaks recommended by other reviewers. I made the salad dressing in a bottle and added 1/4 t chili paste and a reason of sesame oil. I used bagged cabbage mix and broccoli slaw. I also added some mandarin oranges which added sweet flavor and some avocado (I love avocados). Since this wasn’t for a party, I put the salad in a bowl and only added a few tablespoons of dressings. It was yummy. I can make more as I desire and the dressing will last a few days in the fridge. Great recipe. Thanks.
I shrunk it down for 4 servings and added toasted slivered almonds...yum!
This is my new go to Asian dressing. Reminds me of a local hibachi restaurant recipe. Perfect combination of sweet and salty.
Was really good. Used prepackaged coleslaw, halved the amount of oil , added a little Sriracha to the dressing and added some chicken. Came out good, will make again.
Great tasting coleslaw! I didn’t put the Napa cabbage in since I didn’t have any on hand. I used the coleslaw in spicy Thai chicken lettuce wraps. I’ve made it twice now.

Deep regards to the one who shared the recipe. The peanut butter dressing tasted excellent par' just as is. Added some sliced and furled red onions very thin - an add to all of the other items listed here. Paper thin sliced almonds and rice style sliver-crackers topped this fantasial autumn delight. A delicious Sunday eve or occasional salad.
This was phenomenal!! Loved it as a superb substitute for the normal coleslaw. After getting all the ingredients, it was fairly easy to make. It will definitely be quicker the second go around.
DELICIOUS!

Delicious! I had a recipe I used for years , now it’s been supplanted. Love this version. 
Just a few tweaks I made: . Only 2 tbs. of oil, Only 1 of sugar , 1 cup of cilantro And I bought from my veg. Market a Pre cut mix of cabbage ( not the bag kind this was market cut) Much easier. Took a taste and the ginger just burst in my mouth . Yum!!

Love this dressing! I only wanted enough for 2, so I did the easy math and divided the recipe by 3 LOL. (You have to go down to teaspoons for peanut butter (5 tsp), ginger (2 tsp) and garlic (1.5 tsp). I was trying to use up a half head of red cabbage, which ended up being about 3 cups shredded. I added shredded carrots & thinly sliced Vidalia onion, and dressed it with the amount of dressing I made, which turned out to be the perfect amount. Topped it off with salted sunflower seeds. Very tasty! The red slaw has a heavier presence, so next time, I’ll try the recipe as written with the green cabbage.
Absolutely great dressing! I substituted lettuce for green cabbage and it was so good, just be sure it’s all going to be eaten that night because the lettuce wilts fast in the rice wine vinegar

We loved this! The dressing we made as written the first time. The second time I added an extra tablespoon and half of white wine vinegar. We had to change the base of the slaw, because we had cabbage in the garden that needed harvesting. We used all regular cabbage. I shredded the carrots (adding one extra, because I love carrots). We used walking onions because that’s what is growing now. 
This is an excellent base recipe, you can play with. We added black sesame seeds and peanuts to the first batch. Exceptional! We added roasted chicken to the second batch. It was really good too. (I liked the peanuts better than the chicken)
We did not add the dressing the greens. We added it as we made our salads. One of us likes less, one likes more. This way the leftovers the next day are as good On day two, as day one. Thank you to the author for sharing, this is now my favorite slaw.
This coleslaw has a lot of umami to it. Very tasty.
So delicious! We have this almost weekly.

This is really good! My husband who is not much into salads, enjoyed it. I added some crunchy tofu bits and since I didn't have carrots, I used some sliced apples and it worked well. I also did not have any bell pepper, yet it was still flavorful. I served this as a side dish to a chicken fillet lunch.
good

REDUCE GARLIC & GINGER! I love garlic more than anyone I know but was SO GLAD I stopped at 2/3 the amount listed; my mouth was on garlic-fire all night! Also, 2 T. fresh ginger is SO potent, I used 1/8 tsp ginger powder, it was plenty. Also cut oil in half, didn't miss it, the dressing still DELISH! Dressing so strong and saucy that I had to add a couple more cups cabbage than called for, plus some shredded pork to soak it all up. Next time I'll reduce to 2/3 the dressing amount, and I'll go with HALF the suggested fresh garlic. SUCH A FUN, UNIQUE FLAVOR FOR A SLAW, I'LL MAKE AGAIN AND AGAIN!!!! THANKS for enlivening my kitchen tonight! :)
This was very good. I used a coleslaw mix, green pepper, green onions and cilantro, and cut the dressing in half.

Bagged Cole slaw works perfectly for this. If you add the dressing right before serving it this will be crispy. But if you add the dressing and let it chill for several hours you will get the right texture for slaw! Addding vinegar to cabbage makes it shrink ( you won't have several quarts of it, as one reviewer you're complained!) and give off its liquids. the easiest way to make the dressing is in a small food processor or blender.

We love serving this as a side dish with Asian style pork ribs!

Such a yummy, refreshing summer salad! Pairs well with grilled chicken or pork. I omit the green onions due to personal preference. I have also tried this without the peanut butter because my boyfriend is allergic and it is just as good!
I actually had none veggie eaters go back for seconds!
Everyone loved the dressing flavours. A nice break from standard salad dressing
The tagline is absolutely right...the peanut butter seals the deal.

I loved this recipe, I will make this again for sure. I used packaged salad mix with romaine, chicory, broccoli red cabbage and cauliflower. I made the dressing as recommended with the only exception being That i used refrigerated “squeeze”ginger. Yummy! I used this to top wonton tacos. Yummy!
Turned out awesome!!

This was such a hit! I really didn't alter much. I did read a bunch of reviews first and also cut the oil in half and used olive oil instead. I only had crunchy peanut butter so I put all the dressing ingredients in the magic bullet and mixed it. 
I used shredded cabbage and some broccoli slaw - saved some time and mess. 
I REALLY recommend adding the dressing slowly as you will be surprised at how much it covers and you don't want it to be sopping. 
Delish!
Worked great! Family enjoyed it. Used it as a topper for fish tacos.
We like this!!!

Made it for a church event and it was a big hit. It makes plenty. I used crunchy peanut butter and it added an interesting additional texture. I I was tempted to add some sesame oil, but I'm glad I didn't. Definitely worthy of an encore.
So fresh, crunchy, and versatile! We eat this in soft corn tortillas for a healthy taco meal.

I made this pretty much as written, except I forgot the red peppers. They weren't missed; everyone loved this salad. Everyone at work asked for the recipe. As with most slaws, it doesn't keep very long with the dressing mixed in because it gets soggy (but still tastes great). If I knew that we would be eating on it for a couple of days I might keep the dressing separate. One thing I did different with the dressing was to add half the oil and I added both vegetable oil and sesame oil. This salad would be great with the crunchy Chinese noodles, add some chicken, almonds or sesame seeds...lots of possibilities!
LOVE IT

Very nice twist on cole slaw - we loved the flavor! I used packaged cole slaw - added some green and red bell pepper and some red onion, since that's what I had on hand. I also didn't have creamy PB, but knew we wouldn't mind the chunks of peanuts. Will make again.

I loved the dressing!!! I actually used a pre-shredded bag of mixed cabbage, carrots, etc. I added the rest of the ingredients and it was delicious. I made the recipe to feed 4 and if I did it again I would make extra dressing. Yum!
No changes! And I have made it a few times and will continue to!

I was very pleased with this recipe, I received multiple compliments on the dish during two different events. It's given me a new appreciation for cabbage also. I was always used to having it cooked, and this was a great preparation with now cooking involved.
Made dressing separate and let guests add on salad.
Great side dish next to Thai salmon cakes!
I follow this recipe exactly as written and it is delicious. It makes a big batch that can be eaten throughout the week. I love love love it. Who knew a salad could be addictive.
Mehhhh. Too sweet and dressing was watery.
Delicious! Will make this again, exactly as written.

I followed the ingredients for the Asian sauce as directed except I substituted white vinegar. I only used white cabbage, carrots, and cilantro and then mixed it all up. It was perfect! I wouldn't change a thing! Next time I make this I'll be sure to buy the green onions and red pepper too! Perfect side to go with BBQ brisket.
Love the dressing
Made it just as written. Everyone really liked it. Paired it with mashed potatoes and smoked pork belly. Great dinner.

I absolutely LOVE this recipe! I pair it with the Asian chicken thighs recipe from this site. I sub the thighs for chicken breast, let it marinate overnight, broil to cook, boil the remaining sauce for two minutes and add some corn starch to thicken then use the sauce to baste while cooking and finally toss the cooked chicken in remaining sauce. I cut into chunks and let chill. I make this awesome slaw dressing and mix that with bagged cabbage, the chicken, red pepper, green onion and top with wonton strips! A little of this dressing goes a long way. Absolute heaven!
I made extra peanut sauce to send to my mom! She loved it!
Great recipe! Makes a huge amount - and the dressing is the absolute BEST. A definite keeper to the recipe box!
Very good and easy. I forgot to pound them as others suggested and would want to try that next time. I made a Asian cabbage salad I found here also and made some rice.

I made this dish using Napa cabbage only as I had a very large head. Although it likely wasn't as pretty as the original recipe, it was delicious, satisfying, and different. I paired it with a beef and broccoli stir fry and the textures and flavors were pleasing. My son-in-law gave it a rave review!
Nice flavor. I’d suggest only using half the amount of dressing and reduce the brown sugar and oil by half
I made , the taste very delicious ,I am sure I am going to make again. Thanks for the recipe.

I added a teaspoon of sambal oelek as I like a tad bit of spice. Omitted the cilantro because we don't care for it. Decreased the oil by 1 tablespoon.
We enjoyed this and also had it the next day. I didn't think it was too wilted as others have stated. I did add more shredded veg to the dressing than the recipe called for...maybe that made the difference. Will make again.

This is the slaw recipe I've been looking for. The only thing I changed is using just 1 tablespoon of brown sugar since I don't like sweet. It was just enough. Made second time with sunflower kernels and it was so good. Everyone loved it.
This was so good! I didn't have peanut butter or rice vinegar, so I subbed almond butter and red wine vinegar, and it was still delicious!
We used avocado oil, omitted the sugar, and added some sweet chili Thai sauce. Amazing!
really really yummy! I used grapeseed and sesame oils, and instead of peanut butter I added peanut butter powder and a bit of mayo. Oh and ginger!
This is a very flavorful salad, that will please every palate.

This Slaw will go with just about anything, cant wait to try with pulled pork. Like other reviews I kept the peanut dressing and slaw seperate until ready to serve maintaining the crunchiness I'm looking for! I will try next with a dab of seseme seed oil ...... Awesome recipe!
A lot of ingredients, but it is delicious! I used it for tuna steak tacos.
Very tasty and light, went great with sesame seared salmon!
Awesome—loved it over rice
Oh my gosh, worth the effort; so good!
Great recipe! Easy and delicious!
Needs sesame oil for real Asian flavor. Lime juice a welcome addition as was Sriracha. Balance any added lime juice with more brown sugar. Goes great with bulgogi beef in Asian tacos.

I asked my son if he would rate it 5 out of 5 stars, he said no, 200! I left out onions and red bell pepper taking it back to be a bit basic and the kids have asked for thirds on the veggies tonight, thank goodness it makes enough to feed an army. Pairs with Hawaiian chicken sliders.
Really good!

Delicious! I modified the amount as well as the veggies. I used green cabbage, celery, cucumber and it turned out great. 
Great tip to run the ginger through the garlic press!
I used very little oil and eye balled everything else.
I used the bagged cole slaw mix with purple cabbage and carrots instead of chopping all the different kinds of cabbages. Everyone thought it was swell.

Easy and flexible. I used 1/2 a red cabbage, 2 julienned carrots and 1 red pepper. I used half measurements of the dressing ingredients and made the following substitutions: peanut butter for cashew butter (that's what I had at the time); added 2 tablespoons of Mirin sauce; squeezed a large half lemon at the end. The cashew butter turned out to be a great substitute as it is more neutral on the palette and allows for all the other flavors to come through. The sprinkle of lemon juice at the end also lightened up the taste. My husband and I ate it served on tortilla chips...
I add Sriracha & sesame oil, sometimes I cheat & use bagged slaw - add fresh ginger & honey . I am always asked for the recipe
so good!

My husband and I are addicted to this salad. I have made it so many times since I found the recipe. I made it to a T the first time, but have since gotten lazy and gone to the various bag cabbage mixes to save time. I found some honey chipotle peanuts we like to add to it. They are a bit spicy, so hubby puts more on than me. We have not changed the dressing as we really like it as is. I do use olive oil because I don't buy vegetable oil. Give it a try and if you need a time saver the broccoli slaw you can buy in produce department is so delicious and easy to use. I noticed people saying it got mushy the next day. I never put the dressing on the whole salad. We just put it on our individual salads, so we can have it for days. UPDATE: We have been making this so much. Time saver tips we like.. garlic in the jar, ginger paste in a tube, bagged shredded broccoli, and dry rice noodles in a can. Makes prep so fast!

My husband and I are addicted to this salad. I have made it so many times since I found the recipe. I made it to a T the first time, but have since gotten lazy and gone to the various bag cabbage mixes to save time. I found some honey chipotle peanuts we like to add to it. They are a bit spicy, so hubby puts more on than me. We have not changed the dressing as we really like it as is. I do use olive oil because I don't buy vegetable oil. Give it a try and if you need a time saver the broccoli slaw you can buy in produce department is so delicious and easy to use. I noticed people saying it got mushy the next day. I never put the dressing on the whole salad. We just put it on our individual salads, so we can have it for days. UPDATE: We have been making this so much. Time saver tips we like.. garlic in the jar, ginger paste in a tube, bagged shredded broccoli, and dry rice noodles in a can. Makes prep so fast!

I was emailed this recipe and asked to make this slaw for a family gathering with an Asian food themed dinner. To be honest, I wasn't optimistic. I'm not a fan of traditional slaw. Surprisingly, this slaw with its amazing peanut, ginger, garlic dressing was out of this world and has become a staple in our home. My picky rarely-veggie-eating daughter loves it so I couldn't be more pleased as I struggle to help her eat well. I generally make twice the amount of dressing and sometimes wrap the salad in spring roll wrappers and Miss Picky brings them for her lunch. Delicious!

I used red cabbage only. It's what I had on hand. It really held up to the dressing well. I used half the amount of oil as recommended by others and used sesame oil instead. That really made a great Asian flavor. Added some shelled edamame as well.
Very yummy ! Best coleslaw ever !
My husband and I loved this recipe! Six stars! Used nappa cabbage, no red or regular cabbage. Added 1 cup endive. Coconut aminos in place of soy due to allergy.
This was refreshingly different! I cut the oil by 1 T and added a little Agave just to sweeten the sauce a tiny bit. Also added some coarse chopped cashews just before serving.

I like this recipe as an idea generator, but find the dressing overpowering as written. I use only 2 Tbsp oil, 3 Tbsp peanut butter, about half the vinegar, and add in a tsp of hoisin sauce, a tsp oyster sauce, and a Tbsp sesame oil. We use pre-chopped slaw and broccoli slaw, and dice onion to add as well. With these changes we love it. Thank you for a great base recipe!
First day: You need to be in the mood of oriental food otherwise it is too strong. After a day rest flavours were not that empowering, the creamy of the peanut took over and balanced all together.
Added onion, red pepper, cabbage, and carrot. Added leftover pb sauce and added rice vinegar, oil, ginger to smooth runny consistancy. Delicious!
Good recipe however you do not need to use all the dressing or you will end up with over dressed soggy slaw. I cut the dressing measurements in half and it still turned out well dressed.
I've made it three days in a row.... Love it
Everyone loved this but I did make some changes. I halved the recipe and after all was mixed I added just a drizzle of sesame oil. Mixed again and served. Excellent!
This was a huge hit at dinner tonight! Even my daughter who doesn't care much for peanut dressing gave it a thumbs up. I'm definitely making it again.

I loved the dressing! However, 2/3 of it was plenty for the salad (I am not a heavy dressing person). I think next time I would use red onion instead of green onion for a little more tang. I would also add some raw peanuts. I used green pepper instead of red (since I had it) red would have been better.
Added toasted ramen noodles, sliced almonds and sesame seeds
Very good. Dressing tastes like sauce used for Spring Rolls.
This was outstanding. I used less oil as some other reviewers suggested and I omitted the brown sugar completely. The flavors were great!
Love it! I top with peanuts. And just use one cabbage for simplicity sake.
